thread.title: Houston, Kalanick and Zuck walk into a headline
thread.title_full: Houston, Kalanick and Zuck walk into a headline

author: Jordan Crook
title: Houston, Kalanick and Zuck walk into a headline
text:
Houston, Kalanick and Zuck walk into a headline Posted Advertisement And a bar called SPiN, where photos of them playing ping-pong have the tech media in a great mood this Friday. The reason? At the same time as Houstonâ€™s birthday fun, SPiN was also holding itâ€™s own, separate â€œBabes & Ballsâ€ party with â€œBreakfast at Tiffanyâ€™sâ€ as the theme.
Letâ€™s start from the beginning: 
Last weekend, Dropbox CEO and founder Drew Houston celebrated his birthday with a dinner at Babu Ji in the Mission District in San Francisco, which was attended by Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Uber CEO Travis Kalanick. 
After the dinner, the group went to play some Ping-Pong at SPiN in San Francisco. Thatâ€™s where the â€œBabes & Balls: Breakfast at Tiffanyâ€™sâ€ party comes into play. 
Photos surfaced within the â€œBabes & Ballsâ€ Facebook photo album of the three CEOs playing ping-pong, which is how they ended up in this shit-storm of unflattering optics. drewbirthdaycake Previous Next Exit 
Itâ€™s still unclear if Zuckerberg and Kalanick knew that the â€œBabes & Ballsâ€ party was going down at SPiN, but Houston was listed as Going/Went to the BAB party on Facebook. We reached out to Dropbox and the company did not immediately respond to our inquiry. Weâ€™ll update the post if we hear back. 
We also spoke with Amy Chan, CMO at SPiN and host of the party, to ask if Houstonâ€™s birthday bash was connected to the Babes & Balls party. 
She said that her friend (who was in attendance at Houstonâ€™s birthday dinner) knew about the â€œBABâ€ party and was the one who arranged to have space set up at SPiN for the group. 
â€œThe party wasnâ€™t for Drew at all,â€ said Chang. â€œThey just happened to come during our party. And since it was his birthday, we brought out a birthday dessert like we do for many of our guests.â€ 
Obviously, it doesnâ€™t look great when some of the tech worldâ€™s (and justâ€¦ the worldâ€™s) most powerful men to have their photos in the â€œBabes & Ballsâ€ Facebook photo album , especially if one of them actually RSVPâ€™d to an event with that name. 
One source who was at SPiN that night told TechCrunch that Zuck didnâ€™t know that they were going to a club or that the party was called Babes & Balls. Other sources told Fortune that Kalanick didnâ€™t know the theme of the party before arriving, either. 
The Uber CEO is coming off of a rough few weeks, especially with regard to sexism. The company has been under fire lately after allegations of sexual harassment and a culture that either protects or ignores it . 
Thatâ€™s not to mention the video of Kalanick arguing with an Uber driver over fare wages , or the recently exposed â€œGreyballâ€ program that Uber allegedly used to thwart authorities across the world who were cracking down on the ride-sharing service. 
And so, when news surfaced that Kalanick, Houston and Zuck were at a party called â€œBabes & Balls,â€ the resulting headlines were inevitable: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick played pingpong with Mark Zuckerberg at a party called â€˜Babes and Ballsâ€™ Uber CEO Travis Kalanick and Mark Zuckerberg Celebrate Friendâ€™s Birthday at â€˜Babes and Ballsâ€™ Party Mark Zuckerberg and Travis Kalanick laugh it up at â€˜Babes and Ballsâ€™ party â€˜Sexistâ€™ Tech Moguls Under Fire For Attending Exclusive â€˜Babes and Ballsâ€™ Party Zuck and the Uber villain went to a shitty ping pong party called babes and balls so tech remains unchanged in 2017 pic.twitter.com/OT5UuoQ8O4 
â€” Richie Nakanoâœ¨ğŸš€ğŸ›°ğŸŒ™ (@linecook) March 9, 2017 
It makes sense, while under so much pressure, that Kalanick would want to kick back and enjoy a fun night with his friends. Heâ€™s also known to play by his own rules and apologize later , if at all. 
But youâ€™d hope that the men who are shaping our culture, and setting examples for thousands of young founders every day, would recognize the public perception of being at a party called Babes & Balls. That they have a responsibility to represent massive workforces, an industry, and entrepreneurs everywhere. 
That said, if Zuck and Kalanick had no idea they were arriving at SPiNâ€™s Babes & Balls night â€” which, aside from the name, is said to be rather tame â€” Iâ€™m not sure what the â€˜rightâ€™ course of action would be. Do they all leave? Do they refuse photos? Did they even know the name of the party until after they left? 
Thereâ€™s no evidence that Houston, Kalanick and Zuck did anything at SPiN other than play some Ping-Pong (with Olympic table tennis player Lily Zhang!) and enjoy dessert. 
Yes, Houston knew he was going to an event called Babes & Balls as evidenced by his RSVP. And sure, he should be more careful to avoid putting himself, and his friends, in this situation. But he didnâ€™t name the party. So Iâ€™m reserving the lionâ€™s share of my judgment for SPiN and Amy Chan for a name that is at worst sexist, but also the least clever alliteration ever. 
The tech industry is currently â€œballsâ€ deep into a public excoriation of its treatment of and outlook towards women, which is how a relatively lame birthday afterparty made the news. It emphasizes how much more aware people are becoming of the optics and realities of sexism in tech. The communityâ€™s immune system is waking up â€” letâ€™s hope it tackles some very real issues like the way women are paid, hired and treated in tech workplaces. 0
